quote: When my husband was alive we ran the    business together.  And I managed to    put away a bit of latinum every year,    just for myself.  Now that he's    gone... Well, I've got quite a little    sum...
That's important...
To be honest... It's not really    enough.  Not for the future.  Not    for the way I want to live out my    retirement...       So I've decided to invest it all --
I can't believe I'm telling you    this... We just met.
But I think I can really trust you.     I feel like we've known each other    forever.
When hearts are in sympathy... time    collapses...
I'm taking everything I've saved,    and I'm purchasing the mining    concession for the entire Vlugta    asteroid belt.
Asteroid mining?  How adventurous.       But are you sure that's wise?     Prospecting can be risky.

Not this time.       My father was a stellar cartographer.     Thirty years ago, he conducted a    full spectrum mineralogical analysis    of those asteroids.  But he never    had the means to follow up on what    he found.
And now you plan to carry out your    father's dream.

When his survey results become public,    I'll get seven times my investment    back... overnight.       I still can't believe I'm telling    you all this.  My "secret plan."    I've been thinking about it for years.     I never even told my husband... it    must be all this Gamzian wine.
How brave of you... handling    everything on your own...
It hasn't been easy.  There's so    much to keep track of... so much to    do.
Maybe I can help.       Would you consider... Some kind    of... partnership?
Let's go.
Exactly where are we going?
To Security.
But I've done nothing wrong.
It's true.  We were just talking.
You were talking, Madam.  He was    listening.
Security Chief Odo, isn't it?
I've been watching you since you    arrived.
Should I be flattered?
Martus Mazur... A refuge from the    El-Aurian system...
Everyone has to be from somewhere.       Where are you from, Odo?
Don't try to pull that routine on    me.
What routine?
I know all about you El-Aurians.     You're "listeners."  People like to    talk to you.
Everyone needs someone to confide    in... Someone to hear their stories...    I offer a sympathetic ear.  And if    they request my help -- I give it to    them.
That couple from Pythro Five told me    you asked for their financial access    codes.
Some might call helping an elderly    couple invest their savings a    compassionate act.
Not when you invest it in your own    business.  A business that promptly    folds.
I had a run of bad luck.  No one    regrets it more than I do.
You're a con man.  And they've signed    a complaint.
This isn't necessary.  I'm not going    anywhere.  Let's have a drink.  Talk    a bit...
Chief.
Oh.  Hello, Doctor...
Great job.  You built it yourself,    didn't you?
Yeah.  Just finished.  I missed    playing.  And I figured there'd be    at least a couple of players on board.
I didn't think you'd be one of them.
Captain of the team at Starfleet    Medical School.  We took the sector    championship my last year.
Against other medical students.
Against everybody.       I played a Vulcan in the finals.     Talk about stamina -- I don't think    he ever actually broke a sweat.
And you won?
Took him on a back wall riser shot.
Well, I can't say I've had much in    the way of...    (a look at the weird     exercise)   ... formal training.
But it's been a serious pastime for    a lot of years.
Some of the toughest players I've    run into didn't know what they were    doing --

-- formally I mean.  Hey, whatever    works, works.       This exercise for example.  I picked    it up at a tournament from a top    player.  It's a four thousand year    old battle warmup.  According to    legend, it "makes the heart a friend    to the hand."
Medically, I don't know what that    means.  All I know is it gives me    more energy.
Feel like playing?
Serve.
I'd guess from the lines you prefer    Old Style rules.
I can play any style you want.
Traditional it is.  Always been my    personal favorite anyway --
-- Serve.
One...
Pardon me, Friend.
Pardon me.
Ugh...
Friend?  Are you all right... ?
I thought you had died.
If only...
If only I could be so fortunate.
You were snoring.
Forgive me.  But as you can see, my    health is not good.
Yes.  Well, sorry I had to wake you.
I wasn't always like this.
Of course not.
I had youth.  Vigor.  Fame.  Wealth    beyond measure.  All gone...
I'm not listening...
All because of this.
A gambling device.
Did you win?
Of course not.
You gambled away everything you had?
In a manner of speaking.       Every trade deal I struck was a    disaster.  Every alliance I formed    fell apart.  Every endeavor backed --    a failure.
What does that have to do with a    toy?  Sounds like you just had a lot    of rotten luck.
Yes.  "Rotten luck."  In the end...       It all comes down to luck.
I... won...
That's nice...       What did you win... ?
You dropped it...
Officer!  You've got a dead prisoner    in here!       Officer...
How'd it go?
Good workout?
Medical school.  Captain of the team --    at Medical school.
Who are you talking about?
Bashir.
You had a game?
No.  He had a game.  I just kind of    stumbled around the court for ninety    minutes and made a complete ass of    myself.
I'm sure he didn't see it that    way.
The hell he didn't.  That smug look    on his face.  "I guess you prefer    Old Style rules."  Like I'm some    kind of a fossil.  In my day, I    would've wiped the court with him.
That's the point.  You're not a kid    anymore.  It's nothing to be ashamed    of.  People just naturally... slow    down.
Like molasses in winter.  Thanks.
Miles... You're taking this way too    seriously.
I'm out of shape, that's all.  I    need to get my wind back.  "Sector    Champion" my eye.  He's vulnerable    to every one of my best shots.       I just couldn't get them there.
(continuing; with     intent)   This time...
I thought he was going to have a    heart attack.
Come on, Julian.  It couldn't have    been that bad.
No, really.  His face was flushed.     I could've taken his pulse just by    watching the side of his neck.
Then why didn't you stop?
Don't think I didn't try.  After the    first game, I said I had an    appointment.  He ignored me.  Then    after the second, I said I was getting    tired.  He didn't believe me.
Then he broke his racquet and I    figured finally.  But no.  He made    me stay there while he went and    replicated another one.
So what finally happened?
While he was gone, I called my    assistant.  Told her to call me back    after five minutes and say there was    an emergency in the Infirmary.
That's terrible.
I had no other way out!  Otherwise    there would have been an emergency --    Chief O'Brien's coronary!
At least it's all over.
That's just it.  This is only the    beginning.
The Chief wants a rematch.  I'm    telling you... it's going to kill    him.
Honestly, Julian.  You're    exaggerating.  O'Brien's not a day    over thirty-eight...
Too young to die...

I guess I am overstating the health    risk.  But that's not the point.     The Chief has a lot of pride.  And    for good reason.  I really respect    him -- the things he's done, the    kind of man he is.
I don't want to humiliate him...
Another winner.  What luck...
The Pythron couple has refused to    press charges.
Of course.  Didn't I tell you?     They're my friends.
You can go.
All right.  Double or nothing.
House always takes blue.
Sorry.  The drink's on you.
Prosecco.
And how do you plan on paying for    that?       With "charm?" perhaps?
Double or nothing?
Double nothing is still nothing.
If I lose, I'll give you this.
House always takes blue.
Lucky.
My luck's running good today.
So I heard.       Decided not to testify, did they?
I don't know what you mean.
No?

The forty-seventh Rule of Acquisition    says "Don't trust a man wearing a    better suit than your own."  Either    you're a con artist or you're covering    up an empty coin purse.       I happen to know it's both.
I suppose we can't all be as    successful as you.
Too true.
Some kind of game?       I've never seen that one before.     How do you play?
Just push that key.
Too bad.
As I said.  My luck's running good    today.
Am I supposed to be impressed?
A little tinkering, some replication    and expansion.  It might make a nice    addition to your casino.
Who would play this?  It's a child's    toy.    (as if getting an     idea)   My nephew.  It might keep him out of    my ears for a couple of days.
I'll take it.
That's a tidy sum.
I'm feeling benevolent today.       Have another.
I might have accepted.  But the offer    of the drink... That tells me you're    very interested.
Nonsense.  You read too much into    nothing.  My benevolence is known    far and wide.
Oh, it's legendary, I'm sure.       I'll take one hundred times what    you've got here.
Not in this space-time continuum you    won't.       Go try to peddle this little    triviality down on Bajor.  You might    be able to trade it for a meal.  But    it won't be a hot one.
You'd be in profit by the end of the    week.
Final offer.  Take it before my    magnanimity fades.
Perhaps I'll hang onto it a bit    longer...
Suit yourself.  But be under no    illusions.  If I had been serious    about acquiring this -- it would be    mine.  And for substantially less    than what you'd hoped for.
It seems overconfidence comes in    small packages around here.
My track record speaks for itself.       Just like your security file.
Thanks for the drink.
Times are difficult...
Oh, it's not that.  Business is    good...
Then why are you shutting down?
My husband and I ran this place for    nine years.  Before that we had a    shop on Bajor for seventeen.  But he    passed away a few months ago.  And    my heart just isn't in it anymore.
Not the same, is it?  Working by    yourself...
No.  It's so much nicer to work next    to someone else.       You understand.
Nice shot!
Damn.
You think I'm stupid, too?
What are you talking about?
I don't need your charity.  Next    time, you play your best game or you    don't play.
He can't do this!  I have an exclusive    contract!  I want him arrested!
Who are you talking about?
Martus!  That...       listener.
What's he done?
Just look.
Welcome my friends.  Welcome... to    Club Martus.
I have a contract!  For which I paid    considerably.  All gambling on DS    Nine happens at Quark's -- or it    doesn't happen.
A few bribes to the Cardassians when    they ran this place doesn't constitute    a contract.  Not in the eyes of the    Federation.
He's a con-artist!  A crook!
One more won't make much difference.
You owe me.  You begged me to stay    here when you came on board and I    did -- against my better judgement.
I didn't beg.  I blackmailed you.       And don't pretend it hasn't paid off    for you.
It's paid off fine until now!  Martus    is cutting into my profits.  I want    him stopped before it gets any worse.
Too late for that, my Brother.
What is the meaning of this?
I've promised your underpaid sibling    a quarter partnership in my    establishment.
Make me a better offer.
A bidding war?  Over you?  Don't    make me laugh.
Careful, Martus.  He shaves the    latinum!
I do not.       Not much...
Martus, I just got word that the    Vlugta government accepted my bid.
That's wonderful.       What's wrong?

They won't finalize the transaction    unless I commission a study on the    effects the asteroid mining will    have on intersystem navigation.       All my money is committed to the    bid.  I can't afford the study.  And    I only have a week to get it done.
How much do you need?
Ten thousand Vlugtan Isiks.
Ten thousand Isiks... It won't be    easy to raise that kind of money.
I know.  I hope I can find an investor    in time.
I might know someone.  But what kind    of return could they expect on their    investment?
Once I begin mining, I'll pay them    ten times ten thousand.
Don't worry, Alsia.  I'll do    everything in my power to keep your    dream alive.
Martus, I don't know how to thank    you.
Is there a problem, Rom?
Not with this batch... but with my    brother around... you can never be    too careful.
You mean to say he would poison the    canapes?
Maybe not poison.  But a small    intestinal bug... I wouldn't put it    past him.
Don't worry about Quark.  I've been    having the most astonishing run of    luck lately.       I'm beginning to think I can do no    wrong...
Neatness counts.  Never think it    doesn't...
A toast!  To the Queen of the    Promenade!
A woman whose business acumen is    matched only by her beauty and charm.       Have I left anything out?
To you, My Treasure...
Are you as pleased as I am?
What do you think?
I think we make quite a good team.       Perhaps we might consider...
... formalizing our relationship...
Are you proposing to me?
What do you think?
It's beautiful...
You deserve nothing less...
What's that?
Come take a look...
I replicated them from a handheld    version a friend gave me.
I've never seen anything like them.
No one has.
House always takes blue...
What a surprise.
House always takes blue.
I don't believe it.
Believe what?
I've had the computer looking for    this program for weeks.  It was buried    somewhere in the deep code level    right before the Cardassians left.
How'd you find it?
I'm not sure.  It's more like it    found me.       Just lucky, I guess.
I'm so sorry!
What... happened...
You served, I returned low, you    slipped on the ball...
I slipped on the ball?
Stepped right on it in mid-flight.     Never seen anything like it.
Easy.  I want to check you out...
I'm fine.  Serve.
Doctor Bashir, report to the    Infirmary.
Sorry, Chief.  Have to go.
I'll get you next time.
Look, about that...       It's just that... I guess I don't    enjoy the game as much as I used to.     I hope you don't mind... but I'm    sure you can find another opponent.
Where is everybody?
My friendly competitor's place.    (serves O'Brien a     drink)   A Listener.  So what?  So he listens.     I can listen.  I can listen as well    as anyone.
What happened?
I fell down.
See.  I'm listening.  Nothing to it.       How did you fall down?
Playing racquetball with Bashir.
Where?
On the court -- where do you think?
What was the score?
Who cares?
I care.  I'm listening.  Tell me    your problems.  All of them.
I've got no problems a good drop    shot wouldn't cure.
He beat you.
By half a step!  That's all.  He's    got a few years on me -- so what?     I've got more experience...
The aging champion...
I've got spin shots he's never even    seen...
Versus the daring challenger...
So I had some bad breaks.  One more    game.  That's all I needed.
Come one, come all...
I'd've kicked him all over the court.
Welcome to Quark's...
Thanks.
Quark's House of Champions...
Damn.
Something wrong, Major.
My terminal just... self-destructed.
What?
I lost an evaluation report I've    been working on for weeks.
Even the backups?
Even the backups.

Funny, I've been hearing a lot of    bad luck stories in the last few    hours.       Doctor Bashir tells me the Infirmary    is full of minor accidents.  People    slipping and falling, walking into    turbolift doors before they open,    that kind of thing.
Well I've had a great day.  So    don't try to send your misfortunes    over here.
Come on.  We make our own luck.  We    all know that.
They all hit jackpots at once?       Is there any way I can blame this on    you?
I don't think so.
No.  I suppose not.       Pay them off.
"Challenge of the Galaxy."  "Match    of the Century."       "Wonder of the Wormhole."
House always takes blue...
If it's action you want, you've come    to the right place.  Excitement...    we have it here!  Thrills and spills.     Victory and defeat.  Look no further.     We've got it all...
Here he is.  The reigning champion    of Starfleet... A legend on both    sides of the wormhole... Ladies and    Gentlemen... Miles "The Mechanic"    O'Brien!
What's this all about?  I got an    emergency call.
So did I.  But I don't see any    emergency.
And the challenger... He's fast,    he's deadly.  He's Julian Bashir.     They call him The Doctor!  The grudge    match of the galaxy...
Get down from there!
And all...       For a worthy cause.
Yes, these noble competitors have    insisted I donate half the house's    winnings to the Bajoran Fund for    Orphans.
Orphans?

The Mechanic versus the Doctor.     Tomorrow.  Twelve hundred hours.     And only one will emerge victorious.     So place your bets.  And in the    meantime...    (indicates gambling     tables)   The tables are open...
Quark, this is outrageous.  We haven't    agreed to anything.
As your exclusive promoter, I have    the right to arrange matches as I    see fit.
Exclusive Promoter?
Just sign here.
Forget it, Quark.

I understand how you feel, but...    think of the children.       The monks have already made a down   payment on new blankets for the    winter.       Ah well, I'm sure the little ones    can huddle together for warmth...
Looks like you're going to get that    rematch after all.
I don't believe it.  The program I    found... It... disappeared.
Have you checked the deep code level?
No luck.       It's funny, it's almost like the    computer brought that program up at    random... then just swallowed it    again.
Major -- you're all right.
Not even a sprain.  But that's more    than I can say for everybody else in    the Infirmary.
Still crowded?
Yeah.  But Doctor Bashir tells me    it's a whole new batch.
More minor accidents?
Could there be a connection between    the accidents and the increase in    system failures?
I wasn't hurt by a system failure.     I tripped and fell.  Just coincidence,    that's all.
There must be a logical explanation    for all this... maybe a virus... or    some kind of spatial disruption?
It would have to be something that    effects both people and machinery.
Get on it.
I always had smaller lobes than the    rest of the boys.  They used to tease    me about it.  Quark was the worst.     He told everyone I was adopted...
I just don't understand.  Things    were going so well...
On my naming day, Quark substituted    old vegetables for my presents.     Then he sold the presents for more    than our father had paid for them.
I couldn't care less about your    trivial childhood.       We've been virtually abandoned.  I    want to know why.
A bad streak.  It happens.
Not to me it doesn't.
I require the comfort of a    compassionate soul.
Don't think I didn't see through you    from the very start.
A joke!  Really.
In case you've forgotten, I still    hold the lease on this place.  I    want you out of here by tomorrow.
But Treasure...
Oh, I knew no good would come of    this.  I never should've left Quark.     What's going to happen now?
I'm not sure.       But I have an idea.
The profits from the club... I believe    it comes to just about ten thousand    Isiks.
Oh, Martus!
You don't know how much this means    to me.
I know what it means to me... ten    times as much in return.
You won't regret this.  You'll see.     We'll both be rich.
You can beat his backhand.  Keep the    ball low and to his left.
Corner return on the serve, then    kill shot left.
If he returns again... high back    wall...
And remember --
-- Win or lose...       Tonight we celebrate.
Miles, wait.
A silk handkerchief... medieval    Japanese design.  Scented with my    perfume.
Kick his butt.
Doctor...       I brought you something, a token of    thanks from the monks... to show how    much they appreciate your    participation in their little    fundraiser.
Thanks.  Put it over there.
Aren't you going to try some?
What is it?

The monks tell me it's a medicinal    brew... an ancient secret of their    order.  It's supposed to impart great    energy and vigor... Just the kind of    thing to have before an athletic    competition.
But you're a man of science.  You    probably don't believe in folk    medicine.
Actually, you'd be surprised how    often traditional medicine turns out    to have genuine value.
What did they say was in this stuff?
They didn't, exactly.  But I'm sure    it's all completely natural.
The monks said you should drink the    whole thing in one gulp in order to    get the proper effect.
Did they?
What are you doing?
Just curious about its contents.
But what about your exercises?
This will only take a second.
Why bother?  Don't you trust the    monks?
Water... Sucrose... Dextrose...    tribnel root extract... grain    particulates... Yeast... synthahol...       And almost seventeen milligrams of    hyvroxilated quint-ethyl metacetamin.
Like I said... all natural.
It's an anesthetic.  If I drank this,    I'd barely be able to stand, let    alone play racquetball.       You were trying to fix the match.
Would I do that?
You would if you had enough latinum    bet on Chief O'Brien...

No one's betting on Chief O'Brien.     All the money's on you.  If you win,    there won't be any profits.  And if    there aren't any profits, I can't    donate anything to the monks.  No    donations... no winter blankets for    the children.       But if you lose, then the house would    win, and the monks would get their    blankets.
Are you suggesting that I throw the    match?
For the children.
Forget it, Quark.
But the blankets...
Will be provided by you one way or    another.  Because if the monks don't    get their blankets, Chief O'Brien    and I will be very upset.       Is that clear?
Perfectly.
Now, if you'll excuse me... I have a    match to play.
Kira said you'd found something.
Oh, I found something all right.  I    just don't know what it means.       Look at this.
Solar neutrinos.
Notice anything unusual?
There're a lot of them?

The spin.  Given the laws of    probability, from any given point of    view, about half of them should be    spinning clockwise and half of them    counterclockwise.    (brings up more     information)   But over eighty percent of them are    spinning clockwise.
You think people are having accidents    because of the way the neutrinos are    spinning?
No, but I think it may be a symptom    of the same problem.  The neutrinos    outside the station are normal, but    inside...       Something very strange is going on    here.
Have a good game, Julian.
You too.
First point, O'Brien, breaking the    serve...       So it begins...
Two-zero, O'Brien.  Not a rousing    start for The Doctor...
Where is she?
Who?
Alsia.  She was supposed to meet me    here and tell me how the bid went.
I still don't think it's fair.  You    investing my money without asking.
Your money?
You promised me one quarter of the    profits.  But then you gave her    everything we earned.
I promised you a quarter of the    profits after expenses.
Expenses?  What expenses?
Operating costs, overhead,    recapitalization...
That does it.
Where are you going?
Back to Quark.  At least that way    I'll get cheated by family.
Let's get out of here.
Another bad break for Bashir.  Nine-   three, O'Brien.
Quark.  I'm cutting the transmission.
What?  You can't.
Watch me.
The players have called a three minute    break!  Betting is reopened!  Three    minutes only!  Three minutes only!
Why did you do that?
Something's wrong here.
With me maybe.  But you're playing a    great game.
The best I've played in my entire    life.       I'm making shots I couldn't make    fifteen years ago.  When I was playing    five hours a day, every day.  I can't    miss.
And I can't hit the broad side of a    Plygorian Mammoth.
Try throwing it against the wall.
It should have come straight back to    me.    (O'Brien picks up the     ball)   You try.
O'Brien to Ops.
It goes right to his hand.  Every    single time.
I must've done it a dozen times by    now.  And I haven't missed once yet.
Nobody can be that lucky.  It's    impossible.
Not impossible.  Just extremely    improbable.
Improbable?
Like the neutrinos on the station    spinning the same way.  Or a few    dozen people having minor accidents    at the same instant.  Or a system    failing at just the wrong time.
Exactly.  Someone or something on    this station is distorting the laws    of probability.
Changing them so that incredibly    unlikely things can happen on a    regular basis.
How can we find out what's causing    it?
I think I know a way.
Ninety-eight percent of the neutrinos    in this room are rotating clockwise.
The games are open...
We're not here to play.       Dax?
One hundred percent clockwise.    (puts away her     tricorder)   It's these machines.
My gambling machines?  What's wrong    with them.
Somehow these machines are altering    the laws of probability all over the    station.
So that's what he meant.
Who?
The alien who gave me the original...    He said that it all came down to    luck.  That must be how it works.     When you win, it makes you lucky,    and when you lose...
But these machines are effecting    everyone on the station, whether    they play them or not.
(trying to dodge     responsibility)   Impossible.  You must be mistaken.
Wait a minute.  You said there was    an original machine?
Yes, a smaller one.  When I opened    the club I replicated these larger    versions...
Larger versions.
How do you turn them off?
I'm not completely sure.
Then how did you turn them on in the    first place?
(realizing he's blown     it bad)   I didn't, exactly.  I just... told    the replicator to scan the original    and make copies.       I think they have some kind of    internal power source.
Lieutenant.
Wait... what are you doing?
Now... as for you...
You can't possibly blame me for this,    Commander.
I'd like to.  Unfortunately, I don't    have anything I can charge you with.
Fortunately, I do.
That elderly Pythron couple you    "assisted" has had a change of heart.     They've decided to press charges    after all.
Alsia.  I knew you'd come to get me    out.
Inside.
What's the meaning of this.
Ask him.
Your lady friend over there just    tried to scam me.
Scam?
Asteroid mining.  To think anyone    would be foolish enough to be taken    in by that old trick.       But don't worry, Martus, I've come    to get you out.
In return for what?
Nothing.  Pure generosity.
You're enjoying this, aren't you?
Taken in by one of your own victims.     And no one to turn to but me.  I    can't remember when I've been so...    entertained.
I'm glad you're enjoying yourself.     Now how about giving me two thousand    Isiks so I can book passage off the    station.
-- You want me to give you money?     Ridiculous.  Of all the ungrateful    arrogance.
Unless you want me to stay here on    the station.
All right.  I'll loan you five hundred    Isiks.  You can book passage on a    cargo ship.
Fifteen hundred.  After all, I do    have expenses.
Six hundred.
Twelve hundred.  I still have my    dignity.
"Dignity and an empty sack is worth    the sack."  Rule of Acquisition number    one hundred nine.
All right.  Eight hundred.
Go on... I'm listening.
